snippet: The tabletop mountains near the Amazon rain forest can be isolated, but they support a wide diversity of species that are found nowhere else on the planet.
abstract: Study in journal Evolution reports first DNA-based evidence that the rare and numerous species of animals and plants found in the tepuis, or tabletop mountains, looming over the Amazon rain forest spent millions of years climbing up the colossal cliffs; study focused on tree frogs, which does not rule out a 'lost world' hypothesis for other species mysteriously surviving in the flat mountain top areas. (M)d
lead_paragraph: Looming over the northern edge of the Amazon rain forest are some of the most remarkable mountains on earth. Known as tepuis, or tabletop mountains, they are typically ringed by sheer cliffs that rise thousands of feet from the surrounding lowland jungles. Instead of peaks, tepuis have enormous flat expanses at their tops. To reach the tops of many tepuis, the only choices are scaling the cliffs or flying in a helicopter. For all their isolation, the tops of tepuis are not barren. They are like islands in the sky, covered with low forests and shrublands that support a diversity of animals likes frogs and lizards. Many of the species that live on top of the tepuis are found nowhere else on the planet.

headline.main: It's Not So Lonely at the Top: Ecosystems Thrive High in the Sky
